attributes.title: Does Minority Representation in Bureaucracies Reduce Prejudice? Evidence from the COVID-19 Crises in Israel
attributes.description:
Minority representation in bureaucracies is associated with enhanced public goods provision.
Yet, far less is known about its externalities for intergroup relations. I design a survey experiment to test whether information about the role of Arab healthcare workers in responding to the COVID-19 crises, reduces Jewish prejudice and promotes more inclusionary political attitudes. I further test whether politicians’ exclusionary statements, attenuate the effects of minority representation on prejudice, and whether the severity of the COVID-19 crises amplifies the effects of minority representation on prejudice. I theorize and provide suggestive evidence that the effects of representation on prejudice, are driven by a mechanism of change in perceived social norms.

q2.value:
H1: Information about minority representation in state bureaucracies reduces prejudice

H2: Exclusionary political statements attenuate the effects of minority representation in state
bureaucracies on prejudice

H3: The severity of crisis amplifies the effects of minority representation in state bureaucracies
on prejudice

H4: The effects of representation on prejudice are driven by perceived social norms of inclusion

H5: Partisanship moderates the main effect of representation, such that larger effects will be registered amongst left wing partisans

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
2x2x2 experimental vignette in which I described current events during the COVID-19 epidemic in Israel. Treatments include additional information about:
1. The severity of the COVID-19 epidemic in Israel
2. The fact that many Arab citizens work in healthcare provision
3. Exclusionary statements by Israeli MKs towards Arabs

q7.value: Simple randomization of 3 treatments at the individual-respondent level.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited by IPanel, a fee-for-service Israeli company. Participants are payed according to IPanel procedures (I will pay the company 4.88NIS per participant). Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q12.value: Sample size was informed by a power analysis described in my attached pre-analysis plan.

question.value:
Treatment 1: Arab representation -- Information regarding the representation of Arabs in the healthcare system.

Treatment 2: Severity of COVID-19 -- Information emphasizing that COVID-19 imposes serious challenges to the Israeli healthcare system and society.

Treatment 3: Exclusion -- Information about exclusionary statements made by Israeli MKs towards Arabs. 

*A full description of all treatments and their translation to english is provided in my attached PAP.

Demographics

1. Gender
2. Age
3. Ethnicity
4. Religiosity
5. Education
6. Locality
7. Partisanship

Prejudice Outcomes 

8. Feeling Thermometers: Left wing supporters, right wing supporters, Arabs
(0:100)
9. Social Distance: What is the maximum level of proximity which you would accept with
Left-wing supporters / Right-wing supporters/ Arabs? 
(1. Not accept in my country, 2.Accept as guest in my country, 3. Accept as citizen in my country, 4. Accept as co-worker, 5.Accept as neighbor, 6. Accept as close friend, 7. Accept as family through marriage)
10. To what extent to you agree with the following statements?
(0:7 Likert scale)
-? It is possible to trust most Arabs
- Most Arabs want to live in peace
-? Arab MKs should lead Knesset committees

Perceived Norms (H4 Mechanism)
12. To what extent to you agree with the following statements?
(0:7 Likert scale)
-? Most Jews are willing to receive treatment from an Arab doctor
-? Most Jews are willing to maintain friendship with an Arab citizen
-? Most Jews are willing to work for an Arab boss
-? Most Jews are willing to have Arab MKs lead Knesset committees

Manipulation Check
13. To what extent to you agree with the following statements?
(0:7 Likert scale)
-? The effects of COVID-19 on Israeli society will be very severe
-? Arab doctors are at the forefront of the battle against COVID-19
-? Many MKs are against having Arab Knesset members filling important political positions
in the government and the Knesset

For a detailed description of my analysis plan please see the attached PAP


For H1 I implement the following OLS model:

y_i = a +b1*DOC_i+e_i

My main parameter of interest is b1 which represents the effects of information about Arab doctors. 

For robustness, I will estimate a version fo this model with pre-treatment demographics( Gender, Age, Ethnicity, Religiosity,  Education, Locality, Partisanship), controlling for additional treatments.

For H2-3

yi = a +b1*DOC_i+b2*Mod_i+b3_i*(DOC *MOD)+ei

My main parameter of interest is b3 which represents the moderating effect of the additional treatment (severity/exclusionary statements) on the Arab doctor treatment.


For H4 I implement the following OLS model:

y_i = a +b1*DOC_i+e_i

My main parameter of interest is b1 which represents the effects of information about Arab doctors. My outcome in this case will be the survey items related to perceived social norms. 

For robustness, I will estimate a version fo this model with pre-treatment demographics( Gender, Age, Ethnicity, Religiosity,  Education, Locality, Partisanship), controlling for additional treatments.


For H5 I implement the following OLS model amongst two subsample -- Right and Left wing partisans. My main parameter of interest is b1

y_i = a +b1*DOC_i+e_i

q22.value: I plan to further consider how my severity treatment affects polarization between right-and left-wing voters. To do so, I create a polarization outcomes using feeling thermometers and Social distance scales (In-group-Out-group). I regress this measure over the severity treatment to explore whether extreme crises reduce polarization. I will also explore whether exclusionary statements towards Arabs reduce polarization.

attributes.title: Perceived economic inequality in everyday life and dehumanization
attributes.description: This is the preregistration for an study in which we aimed to explore the possible link between the perceived economic inequality in the everyday context and the humanity that it is ascribed to poor and rich groups.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Perceived economic inequality in everyday life and dehumanization (CORRELATIONAL STUDY)

other.value: In que questionnaire, we will include some items related to the tolerance to economic inequality (Wiwad et al., 2019) and some items related to the support for social policies (Sainz et al., 2019). These items are included for exploratory purposes and will be part of a different project.

sample.value: Sample size will be computed for a small effect in a regression analysis (α = .05, 80% Power) by using G-Power analysis (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner & Lang, 2009),

analyses.value: Descriptives, correlations, and regressión analysis to test our main predictions.

dependent.value:
Perceived economic inequality in everyday life. A 12 item scale of economic inequality in everyday life (e.g., “I know people with very different levels of economic” or “Among the people I know, some have bigger and more luxurious homes than others”) from García-Castro, Willis and Rodríguez-Bailón (2019) will be use. Answer will be from 1 (completely disagree) to 7 (completely agree).

Blatant dehumanization. Participants will rate the extend they consider that the poor and the rich groups within their society are considered as being less (animal-like) or more (human-like) evolved, by using a single slider for each group that goes from 0 (least evolved) to 100 (most evolved). As in the original procedure (Kteily, Bruneau, Waytz, & Cotterill, 2015), some filler groups (e.g., inmigrants, business men) will be included to cover up the aim of the study. 

Participants socioeconomic status (Adler, Epel, Castellazzo, & Ickovics, 2000) will be also measure and use it as a covariate.

conditions.value: None, this is a correlational study.

hypothesis.value: In this study, we aimed to explore the possible link between the perceived economic inequality in the everyday context and the humanity that it is ascribed to poor and rich groups. Specifically, we expect that higher perception of economic inequality will negatively predict the humanity ascribed to the poor (Hypothesis 1), but positively predict the humanity ascribed to the rich (Hypothesis 2)

attributes.title: Interest Groups and Political Communication, Study 2.1
attributes.description:
Interest groups have become important communicators in political communication. Yet, we know very little about the effects of their interventions. While persuasion research stresses that prior attitudes toward senders, such as credibility assessments, are decisive for acceptance or rejection of messages, it is not clear whether this is also true for interest group communication, given their typically low public profiles. In this, the first of two studies, we examine public profiles and credibility assessments of 10 German interest groups and parties represented in parliament.


This pre-registration contains an analysis pipeline (Stata syntax). Based on synthetic survey data that was generated before data collection, the attached analysis syntax contains both data wrangling steps and the statistical analysis.


This pre-registration is an update submitted on the first day of data collection of an existing pre-registration that was submitted prior to data collection (https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/KQNAU). See section "other" for details.

q1.value: Alexander Wuttke, Andreas Jungherr, Matthias	Mader, Harald Schoen

q2.value:
H2a: Respondents are less likely to express credibility assessments for interest groups than for political parties.
H2b: Respondents are less certain about their credibility assessments of interest groups than about their credibility assessments of political parties.

We consider it an open empirical question whether the patterns expected in H2a, H2b also hold for the small set of interest groups with relatively high public profiles (measured by relative media presence).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Main interest of this study is observational: comparison of credibility-related assessments of different types of interest groups and political parties.

We compare following types of political actors:

Interest Groups with relatively high public profile (assessed by relative media presence in the previous year):
- Greenpeace: 
- Deutsche Umwelthilfe: 
- Naturschutzbund Deutschland (NABU):
- Bund für Umwelt und Naturschutz Deutschland (BUND)
- Germanwatch: 

Interest Groups with relatively low public profile (assessed by media presence in the previous year):
- Deutscher Naturschutzring
- NaturFreunde Deutschland
- Naturschutzform Deutschland
- MUNA: Mensch, Umwelt-, Natur- und Artenschutz
-  Bundesdeutsche Arbeitskreis für Umweltbewusstes Management (B.A.U.M.)

Political Parties: 
-	CDU/CSU;
-	SPD;
-	AfD;
-	FDP;
-	DIE LINKE; 
-	Bündnis 90/Die Grünen.

This study also contains an experimental module that serves as a pre-test for a follow-up study and which is not part of this pre-registration.

q8.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: We will analyze from all participants provided by Respondi who completed the questionnaire and who do not qualify as straightliners on the matrix questions (see pre-registered analysis syntax).

See Questionnaire attached.

Main variables of interest:
Credibility Assessments of Political Parties and Interest Groups#
Certainty of these Credibility Assessments

Unweighted mean indices were computed across indicators using all non-missing indicators for each respondent
1) of share of provided credibility-assessments and 
2) of level of credibility certainty, 
separately for political parties, interest groups with high public profile and interest groups with low public profile.


****** AVAILABILITY OF CREDIBILITY ASSESSMENTS

*** Share of low profile interest groups for which a respondent did not provide a substantive response
* Missing if all indicators are missing
egen cred_low_profile_abs = rowmean(cred_naturschutzring_abs_d cred_naturfreunde_abs_d cred_naturschutzforum_abs_d cred_muna_abs_d cred_arbeitskreis_abs_d)

*** Share of parties for which a respondent did not provide a substantive response
* Missing if all indicators are missing
egen cred_parties_abs = rowmean(cred_union_abs_d cred_spd_abs_d cred_afd_abs_d cred_fdp_abs_d cred_left_abs_d cred_greens_abs_d)


****** CERTAINTY

*** low profile interest groups: average certainty of credibility assessment (if credibility assessment was provided)
egen cert_low_profile_abs = rowmean(cert_naturschutzring cert_naturfreunde cert_naturschutzforum cert_muna cert_arbeitskreis)

*** parties: average certainty of credibility assessment (if credibility assessment was provided)
egen cert_parties_abs = rowmean(cert_union cert_spd cert_afd cert_fdp cert_left cert_greens)

We will make use of two different strategies, formal and descriptive, to test the expected differences in the distribution of credibility assessments regarding interest groups on political parties.

Formally, we conduct null hypothesis significance tests using simple t tests to compare the frequency of unavailable credibility assessments and levels of the certainty of credibility assessments between low profile interest groups and political parties. For these comparisons, we will rely on aggregated group-level indices, that represent averages of the indicators of single actors of interesting groups of low public profile and political parties.


*** H2a: Respondents are less likely to express credibility assessments for interest groups than for political parties

* NHST - Simple test (one-sided, diff > 0 )
ttest cred_low_profile_abs == cred_parties_abs   


*** H2b: Respondents are less certain about their credibility assessments of interest groups than about their credibility assessments of political parties.

* NHST - Simple test (one-sided, diff < 0 )
ttest cert_low_profile_abs == cert_parties_abs  


As these formal tests only entail null hypothesis significance testing, we consider these group-level comparisons of low profile interest groups with political parties as minimal tests of the hypotheses. 

In addition to these formal tests, we will show the distribution of the credibility-related attitudes for each interest groups. These descriptive analyses of the distribution will therefore also allow to assess the magnitude of the expected differences between the types of political actors.

q18.value:
*H2a: Respondents are less likely to express credibility assessments for interest groups than for political parties. 
*(Higher frequency of absent credibility assessments of IGs than of parties)
*(We consider it an open empirical question whether the patterns expected in H2a, H2b also hold for the small set of interest groups with relatively high public profiles (measured by relative media presence)


*** Dummy: Provided credibilty assessment or not
foreach var of varlist cred_greenpeace cred_umwelthilfe cred_nabu cred_bund cred_germanwatch cred_naturschutzring cred_naturfreunde cred_naturschutzforum cred_muna cred_arbeitskreis cred_union cred_spd cred_afd cred_fdp cred_left cred_greens {
		
		gen `var'_abs_d = cond(`var'==.n | `var'==.c, 1, 0)	 // 1 if clicked on "cannot assess" or when questionnaire page was seen but no response was provided
		replace `var'_abs_d = . if `var' == .					// do not consider respondents who have MV for reasons other than not providing a substantive response on the relevant item although they saw it
}

q19.value: One-tailed significance tests in the direction of the pre-registered hypotheses. Alpha=0.05

q20.value:
** Straightliners will be dropped.
** Straightliners are defined as those respondents who provided identical answers to all items on the credibility of parties battery (where at least some differences are to be expected between items)

gen straight_line_2 = 	cred_union == cred_spd	& 	///
							cred_union == cred_afd	& 	///
							cred_union == cred_fdp	& 	///
							cred_union == cred_left	& 	///
							cred_union == cred_greens	&  ///
							!missing(cred_union)
							

							
*Drop Straightliners
drop if straight_line_2 == 1

q21.value: Listwise deletion. No procedures for value imputation will be used.

q23.value:
This pre-registration is an update of an existing pre-registration of the same study: https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/KQNAU

This update was pre-reregistered after screening data from the first respondents during the 
the "soft launch" of the survey. Compared to the original pre-registration, this updated pre-registration modifies one aspect of the analysis pipeline: the exclusion criterion. All remaining aspects of the original pre-registration remain unchanged.

In line with standard practice, we originally pre-registered the intent to exclude all respondents from the analysis who provided identical responses to all items of two long survey batteries ( the battery on the frequency of contact with interest groups in the past month and the battery on the credibility of parties). We initially considered straightlining on the batteries as indicative of non-sensical or non-attentive response behavior. However, upon screening the initial data, it became clear that such response behavior can be plausible and that this exclusion criterion would therefore remove respondents who provided meaningful answers. 
In detail, from the initial 68 responses, the original exclusion criteria would have eliminated 19 respondents. 14 of those 19 respondents provided identical responses to the battery on the perceived frequency of contacts with interest groups in the last four weeks. Upon closer inspections, it became clear that all of these 14 respondents were identified as straightliners for reporting no contacts with none of the interest groups in the past four weeks. This response is plausible and therefore substantively meaningful. Hence, we believe the intended analysis will provide more meaningful results if these respondents are not removed from the sample as straightlining in this case is not necessarily indicative of non-sensical or non-attentive response behavior.

Therefore, on the first day of data collection, we submit an updated pre-registration with a slightly modified exclusion criterion. Respondents are no longer excluded from the analysis when providing identical responses to all items of the battery on perceived frequency of interest group contacts. When submitting this pre-registration 86 respondents had submitted complete interviews.

1) of share of provided credibility-assessments and 
2) of level of credibility certainty, 
separately for political parties, interest groups with high public profile and interest groups with low public profile.


****** AVAILABILITY OF CREDIBILITY ASSESSMENTS

*** Share of low profile interest groups for which a respondent did not provide a substantive response
* Missing if all indicators are missing
egen cred_low_profile_abs = rowmean(cred_naturschutzring_abs_d cred_naturfreunde_abs_d cred_naturschutzforum_abs_d cred_muna_abs_d cred_arbeitskreis_abs_d)

*** Share of parties for which a respondent did not provide a substantive response
* Missing if all indicators are missing
egen cred_parties_abs = rowmean(cred_union_abs_d cred_spd_abs_d cred_afd_abs_d cred_fdp_abs_d cred_left_abs_d cred_greens_abs_d)


****** CERTAINTY

*** low profile interest groups: average certainty of credibility assessment (if credibility assessment was provided)
egen cert_low_profile_abs = rowmean(cert_naturschutzring cert_naturfreunde cert_naturschutzforum cert_muna cert_arbeitskreis)

*** parties: average certainty of credibility assessment (if credibility assessment was provided)
egen cert_parties_abs = rowmean(cert_union cert_spd cert_afd cert_fdp cert_left cert_greens)
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will make use of two different strategies, formal and descriptive, to test the expected differences in the distribution of credibility assessments regarding interest groups on political parties.

Formally, we conduct null hypothesis significance tests using simple t tests to compare the frequency of unavailable credibility assessments and levels of the certainty of credibility assessments between low profile interest groups and political parties. For these comparisons, we will rely on aggregated group-level indices, that represent averages of the indicators of single actors of interesting groups of low public profile and political parties.


*** H2a: Respondents are less likely to express credibility assessments for interest groups than for political parties

* NHST - Simple test (one-sided, diff > 0 )
ttest cred_low_profile_abs == cred_parties_abs   


*** H2b: Respondents are less certain about their credibility assessments of interest groups than about their credibility assessments of political parties.

* NHST - Simple test (one-sided, diff < 0 )
ttest cert_low_profile_abs == cert_parties_abs  


As these formal tests only entail null hypothesis significance testing, we consider these group-level comparisons of low profile interest groups with political parties as minimal tests of the hypotheses. 

In addition to these formal tests, we will show the distribution of the credibility-related attitudes for each interest groups. These descriptive analyses of the distribution will therefore also allow to assess the magnitude of the expected differences between the types of political actors.

attributes.title: Negated adjectives and politeness
attributes.description: Investigating the role of face-management in the interpretation of negated antonyms.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We will investigate the role of participant gender as an exploratory analysis. in addition, we will compare morphologically-complex and simple antonymic pairs.

sample.value: We will collect 90 participants in total (45 across two experimental lists). Each participant completes 40 trials (and 10 additional filler trials).

analyses.value: We will run a cumulative link mixed model including main effects of polarity, context type, their interaction, and random effects for participants and items.

outliers.value: Participants who answer incoherently in the filler trials will be excluded from further analyses (if they answer with 5, 6, or 7 in more than 5 filler trials).

dependent.value: The dependent variable is the degree of negative strengthening. We will measure the degree of negative strengthening by using a 7-point Likert scale anchored at the negated adjective (1) and its antonym (7).

conditions.value: We have two factors with two levels, polarity (positive, negative) and context type (standard, non-standard). We will test 20 positive adjectives and their corresponding negative antonyms. Each participant will see all conditions in a Latin square design (across two experimental lists).

hypothesis.value:
What are the contributions of adjectival polarity and face-threatening potential to the interpretation of negated gradable adjectives? This study investigates whether the polarity asymmetry of negative strengthening (Ruytenbeek et al. 2017) – with negated positive polarity adjectives being more likely to be strengthened than negated negative polarity adjectives – can be explained by face-management and/or adjectival polarity. As a follow up to our experiment registered at osf.io/q3g2n, we will directly compare minimal pairs for standard and non-standard contexts.

Alternative Predictions:
P1: If the polarity asymmetry of negative strengthening is explained by face-management consideration only, we should expect a reversal of the polarity asymmetry in non-standard contexts.
(pos > neg in standard context, neg > pos in non-standard context)

P2: If adjectival polarity and face-management both play a role in explaining the polarity asymmetry of negative strengthening, we should expect the polarity asymmetry in the standard context condition to be stronger than the polarity asymmetry in the non-standard context condition. 
(main effect of polarity (pos > neg) + interaction such that the polarity asymmetry is stronger in standard than non-standard context)

P3: If the adjectival polarity is uniquely responsible for the polarity asymmetry of negative strengthening and face-management does not play a role, we should expect a main effect of polarity (pos > neg) and we should have no difference in strength between the polarity asymmetry in the standard context condition and the polarity asymmetry in the non-standard context condition
(main effect of polarity but no interaction between polarity and context type)

attributes.title: Sociodemographic predictors of unemployment in patients with severe mental illness: an electronic health record cohort study
attributes.description: It is well known that unemployment rates are high for people with severe mental illness. Currently our understanding of the sociodemographic predictors of unemployment for people with severe mental illness largely derives from small and laborious cross-sectional survey studies, which are often not ethnically diverse. Until now it has not been possible to investigate these predictors using large case registers such as electronic health records as patient occupations are poorly recorded and characterised in the structured, drop down fields of these records. We have developed an application using natural language processing methodology to text-mine occupations from the free-text in patient’s clinical records, with high levels of performance. Therefore we now have the ability to investigate the predictors of unemployment in people with severe mental illness in a large, naturalistic study for the first time. The aim of this study is to investigate the sociodemographic predictors of ever experiencing unemployment in a large cohort of patients using secondary mental health services in South London with a diagnosis of severe mental illness.

q2.value: We will test if there are associations between the following sociodemographic predictors and experiencing unemployment in a cohort of patients with severe mental illness: age, gender, ethnicity, marital status, area-level deprivation scores, and diagnosis type (affective/non-affective). As previous research is mixed regarding these predictors, these hypotheses are non-directional.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A retrospective cohort study.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: The data has already been extracted from the electronic health records of patients using secondary mental health services in South London. This is via the Clinical Record Interactive Search (CRIS) application, which de-identifies the data. This includes importing the data from the CRIS application to a saved excel spreadsheet, without cleaning or transforming the data. This has been accessed by Natasha Chilman to check that the key variables have been extracted.

question.value:
The data has already been collected. Further details on the secondary data source (CRIS) as a whole can be found here: https://www.maudsleybrc.nihr.ac.uk/facilities/clinical-record-interactive-search-cris/. Permission to conduct secondary analysis of the data was granted by the CRIS oversight committee (ref 19-041).
This cohort includes patients who have received a diagnosis of severe mental illness according to ICD-10 classifications, which includes schizophrenia spectrum disorders (F2*) and bipolar disorders (F30 & F31). Patients were under South London and Maudsley secondary mental health services (including inpatient and community NHS services) between the years 2006/2007 and 2019. The patient's occupational status was retrieved using a natural language processing application to identify any mentions of unemployment/other employment in the free-text fields of the records of these patients, supplemented by the structured fields for employment in the record. Patients were excluded at point of extraction if they received a diagnosis of dementia before their diagnosis of severe mental illness. Throughout data cleaning, patients will be excluded if they (1) did not have an occupation recorded, (2) had incorrect/implausible date of births recorded (commonly 1900-01-01 in this dataset), or (3) patients with gender as 'unknown' or 'other' (to avoid small aggregate numbers).

q11.value: Prior to the above exclusion criteria to take place during data cleaning, the cohort of patients with severe mental illness includes 37,803 patients. Based on performance of the occupation text-mining application in retrieving patient occupations over CRIS, we expect to include >15,000 patients in our analysis after excluding patients without known occupations.

q12.value: We are able to access a very large number of patient records for this study via the CRIS interface which will have suitable power for analysis.

question.value: N/A - observational study

Key outcome variable: Ever experiencing unemployment – categorised into two groups: having a mention of unemployment in clinical notes/structured field (ever unemployed), or having a mention of other occupational group in clinical notes/structured field (never unemployed). 
Age – age at time of occupation extraction, calculated by date of birth in record
Gender – male/female structured fields in the record
Marital status – structured field in the record
Ethnicity – structured field in the record
Area-level deprivation – Index of Multiple Deprivation scores
Diagnosis – affective/non-affective SMI diagnosis

We will conduct logistic regression analyses using STATA-15 software. We will conduct crude logistic regressions investigating the associations between the sociodemographic variables and experiencing unemployment. We will then conduct adjusted models which will adjust for the other sociodemographic variables in the analysis.

q18.value: Occupational status will be re-coded into two categories: ever unemployed (where the patient has at least one mention of unemployment in their record) or never unemployed (no mention of unemployment in their record). We may re-code the sociodemographic variables into categories if we do not have adequate power to detect differences between the groups already pre-defined by the Clinical Record Interactive Search format, e.g. by grouping 'married' and 'cohabiting' together for the marital status variable. Any transformation of data will be reported clearly with reasons for transformation stated.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the logistic regressions suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q20.value: Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q21.value: Patients with missing occupational data will be excluded from the analysis. We will account for any missing data across the crude and adjusted logistic regression models, to only include complete data.

q23.value:
Dissemination

We will publish our findings in a peer-reviewed psychiatric journal and follow STROBE and RECORD reporting guidelines. We will feed back our findings to the CRIS oversight committee. We will also submit this study for presentation at national and international conferences and meetings, and promote findings on blogs/social media accounts.

Acknowledgements

We would like to thank the personnel at the NIHR Biomedical Research Centre for their ongoing support in this project. We are grateful to Hitesh Shetty for supporting the data extraction, Xingyi Song at the University of Sheffield for his work on developing the application to extract patient occupations from the free-text in CRIS, and Jyoti Sanyal for running the occupation application over the SMI cohort.
This work is independent research funded by the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Biomedical Research Centre at South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust and King’s College London, and part funded by the Health Foundation/Academy of Medical Sciences. JD is funded by the Health Foundation working together with the Academy of Medical Sciences, for a Clinician Scientist Fellowship and by the ESRC in relation to the SEPMD study (ES/S0027215/1).

References

Dr Jay Das-Munshi and colleagues' study on severe mental illness and mortality uses a version of this cohort with different extraction dates: Das-Munshi, J., Chang, C. K., Dutta, R., Morgan, C., Nazroo, J., Stewart, R., & Prince, M. J. (2017). Ethnicity and excess mortality in severe mental illness: a cohort study. The Lancet Psychiatry, 4(5), 389-399.

attributes.title: Can We Trust Survey Estimates of Public Compliance with COVID-19 Regulations?
attributes.description: The COVID-19 pandemic has led governments to instate a large number of restrictions on and recommendations for citizens’ behavior. In order to measure compliance with these measures, our best tool is currently nationally representative surveys that ask citizen to self-report their behavior. Yet to the extent that respondents’ has a desire to deny socially undesirable traits, such as not complying with government strictures in order to stem the tide of an epidemic, estimates of compliance will be biased upwards. To assess the magnitude of this potential problem, this study compares measures of compliance from direct questions and ones estimated from a list-experiment - a response technique that allow respondents to report illicit behaviors without admitting them directly.

q1.value: Martin Vinæs Larsen, Michael Bang Petersen

q2.value: Citizens over-report their compliance with official COVID-19 behavioral recommendations when asked directly about compliance.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Our study is implemented as part of a rolling cross-sectional survey of Danish citizens. In the rolling cross-section respondents are asked directly "whether they hugged or kissed a person outside their immediate family yesterday" - a behavior which is at odds with the recommendation from the Danish Health authorities at the time of the study. For a part of the running time - until we get to 3,000 respondents - we include a list experiment near the end of the survey where the sensitive item is "whether they hugged or kissed a person outside their immediate family ". Each respondent is shown the sensitive item with a probability of .5.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Participants are recruited as part of the rolling cross-section survey from Epinion Denmark's internet panel. Renumeration of the participants in the panel is handled by Epinion. In particular, respondents get some points from answering the survey which they can use to purchase items in Epinions internet shop.

q11.value: The sample size will be approx. 3,000.

q12.value: Assuming a compliance rate of around 95% in the direct question, we will be able to detect under-reporting above 7 percent with 80% statistical power (one-sided p-value). This is laid out in simulation do-file attached to the pre-registration.

q13.value: We include the list-experiment in the rolling cross sectional until we reach >3,000 respondents.

question.value: Translated version of the key questions below. The direct question: Did you kiss or hug a person outside your immediate family? Yes, No, Dont Know. The list experiment: Now we want to ask you about what you did yesterday. We will therefore present a number of statements about your behavior. You do not have to tell us which of the things you did, but simply tell us how many of the things you did. 1. I played an online multi-player game with a person outside my immediate family. 2. I did a cross-word puzzle with a person outside my immediate family. 3. I watched a movie with a person outside my immediate family. 4. I spoke on the phone with a person outside my immediate family. 5. (Sensitive item): I kissed or hugged a person outside my immediate family. How many of these things did you do yesterday? The items are shown in random order to the respondents.

We will calculate the overall proportion of individuals following the advice to not hug and kiss outside their immediate family from both the list experiment and the standard self-report. To calculate the proportion using the list experiment, we will use the standard method of subtracting the average number of behaviors reported in the two conditions.


In addition to this, we will do a linear regression with robust standard errors of the number of behaviors the person did in the list experiment. We will use an indicator for whether the sensitive item was shown in the list as the regressor. Our analysis will be restricted to respondents who said they did not hug or kiss anyone outside their immediate family. In this subgroup, we would expect that the inclusion of the sensitive item has a zero effect on the number of behaviors from the list respondents engaged. If we identify a non-zero positive effect then we know there is over-reporting.

q19.value: We will use a one-sided significance test with an alpha level of .05 for our key test. We use a one-sided test because a negative effect is non-sensical. In particular, a negative effect would imply that respondents did not include some of the other behaviors on the list in their response, because the sensitive item was included.

q22.value: We will look for potential heterogeneity across: age, gender, education, and self-reported concern for the corona-virus.

subjects.text: Public Affairs, Public Policy and Public Administration

attributes.title: STUDY PROTOCOL OF A META-ETHNOGRAPHY OF BARRIERS AND FACILITATORS OF ADHERENCE TO THERAPEUTIC EXERCISE IN INDIVIDUALS WITH MUSCULOSKELETAL CONDITIONS
attributes.description: This qualitative meta-synthesis was designed to appraise and synthesize the evidence on barriers and facilitators of adherence to therapeutic exercise as described by adults with MSK conditions and healthcare professionals in MSK rehabilitation.

q1.value: Folarin Babatunde, Joy MacDermid PhD, Luciana Macedo, Ruby Grewal, Mike Szekeres

q2.value: The interaction among the factors described by the World Health Organization Multidimensional Adherence model would influence adherence to therapeutic exercise more than the impact of each individual factor.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This review is nested in an interpretivist paradigm of meta-ethnography. Interpretivism is a branch of epistemology that strives for the comprehension of reality through subjective meaning. Meta-ethnography is the most broadly used qualitative evidence synthesis method in health and social care research and influences other qualitative evidence synthesis methods. Meta-ethnography is applied to produce new conceptual understanding or higher interpretations and used to develop theory from multiple studies compared to traditional narrative reviews. This review will use the Noblit and Hare (1988) proposed framework for meta-ethnography using seven key steps and the eMERGe reporting guidance (France et al., 2019) to increase confidence in meta-ethnography findings.
Step 1: Getting started
Step 2: Deciding what is relevant 
Step 3: Reading the studies 
Step 4: Determine how the studies are related 
Step 5: Translating studies into each other 
step 6: Synthesizing the translation 
Step 7: Expressing the synthesis

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
We will perform initial exploratory text searches using the keywords: therapeutic AND (exercise OR physical activity) AND (adherence OR concordance OR compliance). This initial step provides an overview of the topic and ensures an adequate number of citations are available to determine a search strategy for reviews on complex topics. The keywords and phrases identified in titles and abstracts and the MeSH/thesaurus terms would be used for a full database search across the following databases; Medline, CENTRAL, Embase, PsychINFO, AMED (Allied and Complementary Medicine Database) and CINAHL from inception to 2018. The list of citations will be screened for duplicates using the citation manager Mendeley. Citation searching and Traditional Pearl Growing will be used to supplement the electronic search. 
 


A data extraction form will be created on Microsoft Excel from each qualitative study on study setting, population, phenomena of interest, study design, methods, findings, and comments. FB will extract data regarding population, sample size (patient, HCP), aims, intervention, data source, analysis, and results from each study. Studies would be tabulated in chronological order from the earliest to the most recent.

q12.value:
1. FB will individually screen study titles and abstracts to ensure they meet the study inclusion criteria. After the screening process, the team will meet to discuss which studies should be included or excluded from the study. The reviewers will discuss until a consensus is reached by much of the team when there is any disagreement. When the team unanimously conclude that a study is unclear, FB will contact the study author for clarification. The author will have three weeks to reply before the article is excluded based on insufficient information. Any new study identified through citation searching and traditional pearl growing will be reviewed by FB to ensure they meet the inclusion criteria outlined above. Where multiple reports of the same study are found, the articles would be compared and only selected if each article presents distinct findings based on different study aims and questions using the same materials.
2. Included studies must meet at least two of the four quality reporting criteria developed by Carroll et al. (2012) regarding study design, participant selection, methods of data collection, and data analysis to assist in the internal validity of this review.

question.value:
FB will create a list of important metaphors, phrases, ideas, and or concepts after an initial tentative assumption about the relationship between studies is established. We will use the definition of concepts, "a meaningful idea that develops by comparing particular instances and explains but not just describe the data.
We will only include concepts that are well articulated without reorganizing the findings and exclude data from analysis when unable to decipher a concept. The team will meet to discuss and develop a collaborative interpretation of each second-order constructs. To ensure interpretations are clear and precise, we will use the author's description of the second-order constructs when described briefly and clearly or our interpretation of the original construct when unclear and lengthy.

1. The individual studies would be entered into the systematic review software EPPI-Reviewer 4. Each study would be read and reread individually until the key themes or concepts are identified
2. Emerging themes will be coded into EPPI-Reviewer 4, and an essential list of phrases, ideas, and concepts would be created on an Excel datasheet.
3. The tabulated data extraction sheet will enable the identification of second-order and first-order concepts from each study. First-order constructs are the original view of the participants in the included studies, and second-order constructs are interpretations of ﬁrst-order narratives by the original authors of the included studies.
We will explore how second-order constructs are related to each order, translating studies into each other.

FB will code and organize the second-order constructs into categories or 'piles' with their description using Nvivo 12 software. This process will be conducted in chronological order starting with the earliest publication. The translation would involve comparing themes and concepts from article 1 with article 2 and the synthesis of these two papers with article 3 and continue until the most recent article

q20.value: None of the selected studies will be eliminated based on quality assessment alone due to the potential risk of eliminating valuable insight from a methodologically weak study.

q22.value: We intend to develop a line of argument synthesis by constantly comparing concepts and suggesting an interpretive order. In this phase, FB will list the translated themes and subthemes in a table, juxtaposed with secondary themes derived from second-order constructs to create third-order constructs (reviewer interpretation). The team will meet to discuss the overarching model that linked the translations and interpretations together to generate a line of argument. This model will bring translations and themes together and formulate them into a whole greater than their different parts (Noblit and Hare, 2006; Britten et al., 2002).

registration_responses.q6.question:
This review is nested in an interpretivist paradigm of meta-ethnography. Interpretivism is a branch of epistemology that strives for the comprehension of reality through subjective meaning. Meta-ethnography is the most broadly used qualitative evidence synthesis method in health and social care research and influences other qualitative evidence synthesis methods. Meta-ethnography is applied to produce new conceptual understanding or higher interpretations and used to develop theory from multiple studies compared to traditional narrative reviews. This review will use the Noblit and Hare (1988) proposed framework for meta-ethnography using seven key steps and the eMERGe reporting guidance (France et al., 2019) to increase confidence in meta-ethnography findings.
Step 1: Getting started
Step 2: Deciding what is relevant 
Step 3: Reading the studies 
Step 4: Determine how the studies are related 
Step 5: Translating studies into each other 
step 6: Synthesizing the translation 
Step 7: Expressing the synthesis

attributes.title: Attentional Bias and Reward
attributes.description: Investigating the impact of reward on attentional bias

q1.value: Effect of attentional bias on eye-movements

q2.value: Stephen Dunne, Helen Knight, Shannon Rafferty

q3.value:
Attentional bias is a phenomenon wherein certain items are preferentially processed at the cost of other items in a visual field (MacLeod, Matthews & Tata, 1896; Field & Cox, 2008). It plays an important role in guiding visual behaviour, and is commonly studied in relation to addiction (Field & Cox, 2008), where the development of addictive behaviours is consistently found to coincide with the development of an attentional bias towards addiction-related stimuli (Boyer & Dickerson, 2003; Constantinou et al., 2010; Jones, Jones, Smith, & Copley, 2003; Lusher, Chandler, & Ball, 2004; Townshend & Duka, 2001; Yaxley & Zwaan, 2005). These biases appear to be causally linked to addictive behaviours. For example, a larger reduction in alcohol-related attentional bias during treatment is related to continued abstinence of alcohol consumption following release from rehabilitation centres (Cox, Hogan, Kristian, & Race, 2002; Flaudias et al., 2013).

Much of what is known about attentional biases stems from research comparing substance abusers and addicted populations with healthy controls across a variety of paradigms, such as the modified Stroop (Lusher et al., 2004; Sharma, Albery, & Cook, 2001), dot probe (Noel et al., 2006) and dual task paradigms (Waters & Green, 2003). These investigations have established that people who are depended on or abuse alcohol have consistently faster reaction times towards task-relevant alcohol-related cues (Jones, Bruce, Livingstone, & Reed, 2006; Jones, Jones, Blundell & Bruce, 2002), and slower reaction times when alcohol-related cues interfere with task goals (Cox, Blount, & Rozak, 2000; Johnsen, Laberg, Cox, Vaksdal, & Hugdahl, 1994) than control participants. These studies have yielded valuable data on how attentional biases manifest in addicted and at-risk individuals. However, despite this, there are some methodological issues regarding the samples used in these investigations and the legitimacy by which these findings can be attributed to the wider population.

Specifically, the use of addicts is problematic because of neurophysiological differences between addicts and the healthy population (Baler & Volkow, 2006; Cardenas, Studholme, Gazdzinski, Durazzo, & Meyerhoff, 2007; George, Potts, Kothman, Martin, & Mukundan, 2004; Goldstein & Volkow, 2011; Medina et al., 2008; Thompson et al., 2004). Long term alcohol abuse is related to a detrimental effect on brain structures relating to cognitive control and executive function such as the prefrontal cortex (George et al., 2004; Goldstein & Volkow, 2011; Medina et al., 2008). Thus, observed differences in attention between abusers and healthy controls may be due to damage to essential neural networks. If the cause of the behavioural differences in addicted populations is due to differences in the brain, the findings observed within these populations cannot be compared to healthy, non-addicted controls – or to gamblers, who also exhibit attentional biases towards gambling-related items, without the confound of neurodisruptive substances (Boyer & Dickerson, 2003). However, despite the strong links between behaviours such as addiction and cognitive processes such as attention, there is currently very little overlap in the literature.

The development of an arbitrary attentional bias has been previously investigated with research finding that an experiment information sheet which mentions the word green on it several times is sufficient to induce an attentional bias in a healthy population which persists for at least two weeks and effects performance on a task even when irrelevant (Knight et al., 2016; 2018). While these studies were able to show that an explicit reference to a stimulus can induce an attentional bias, more implicit attentional bias development has not yet been investigated. The current study aims to address this, by investigating the link between rewarding saccadic eye-movements towards an arbitrary stimulus and the potential development of an attentional bias toward the aforementioned stimulus.

q4.value: If participants can be subconsciously biased to the colour green during the training phase, then this will be reflected in reaction time accuracy changes in the experimental phase compared to the baseline phase of the change-detection task.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Participants will be unaware of the importance of the colour green throughout the study. This will not be referred to in the information sheets or any instructions given to participants. As such, participants will be unaware of the true purpose of the experiment regarding the creation of an attentional bias.

question.value:
The study shall consist of three stages of testing - baseline, training and re-test. Stage 2 will use an eye-tracker. Stages 1 and 3 need only a computer screen and keyboard.

Stages 1 and 3 shall be identical and will be used to examine the baseline levels of attentional bias (stage 1) and potential modifications of attentional bias (stage 3) caused by the middle stage. This shall be achieved via a one-shot change-detection task which is an established method used to examine for attentional biases (Knight et al., 2016; 2018). The one-shot change-detection task will follow the following format: The experiment will begin with the presentation of a fixation cross for 1000ms followed by the stimulus array for 1500ms. The stimulus array will be a black screen with a circular array of six different coloured circles on it, all of the same size. The array will be masked for 100ms (by a completely blank screen), after which the stimulus array will re-appear. When it re-appears, one of the circles in the array may have changed colour into a different colour not currently present. Stimuli will remain present until a response is made. In 25% (45 trials) of trials a green item will be present and will change colour (Congruent Change Trials), in 25% of trials a green item will be present in the display but a different circle will change colour (Incongruent Change Trials), in 25% of trials no green item will be present and one of the other circles will change colour (Neutral Change Trials) and in 25% of trials a green item will be present but no change will occur (No Change Trials). The position of the coloured items will vary randomly across trials. The colours the circles in the array can be will be: green, red, blue, pink, purple, grey, mustard or orange. Participants will be advised that a change can occur to any of the presented stimuli in any position in the array. Participants will be asked to respond as quickly, but as accurately as possible via a computer keyboard if a change occurred or not. Response buttons will be coded to participant handedness (e.g. right-handed participants: M = change / Z = no change). Participants will complete 3 blocks of 60 trials with a 5 minute break between each block.

Stage 2 of the study will be an eye-movement task. Here, participants will be presented with four different coloured shapes on a computer screen. In many trials (but not all), one of these shapes will be a hexagon. If a hexagon is present , it will always be green (though participants will not be told this). Participants will be asked to make an eye-movement towards the hexagon, if it is present, as quickly but as accurately as possible. Once an accurate eye-movement has been made to the hexagon, a new trial will start. If no hexagon is present, they will be asked to press the space bar to start the next trial. The location of the hexagon will vary randomly across trials and the colours and shapes of the distractors on the screen will also vary randomly. Each trial shall be separated by a blank screen for 1000ms to minimise fatigue. Participants will complete 3 blocks of 30 trials.

The data from Stage 1 and 3 (reaction time and accuracy) shall be compared to examine if the middle training stage altered participants ability to detect changes to green items. This shall be done via two repeated measures ANOVAs - one examining differences in stage 1 compared to 2 for each type of trial for reaction time, and the other doing the same for accuracy. Reaction time and accuracy towards green shapes in stage 2 shall also be examined, to ascertain that participants are engaging in the training task appropriately - thus, results from this stage of the experiment will only be analysed as a control and not as part of the overall findings from the experiment.

q9.value: As the experiment is a repeated measures task, no randomisation procedure is necessary.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be primarily recruited through the University of Sunderland's SONA system and will receive course credits for participation through this. Other participants will be recruited via adverts on social media asking if they would like to take part in a spot-the-difference and eye-movement task. Adverts will provide the email address of the two co-investigators (Helen Knight and Stephen Dunne) and will be asked to email either of the investigators to arrange a time for testing.

Full informed consent cannot be obtained from participants before taking part in this study, since previous research has shown that full informed consent when investigating attentional biases is one way to induce an attentional bias. Given that the current research is investigating the implicit development of an attentional bias, the word 'green' nor the mention of biases of attention can be presented to participants before testing has occurred. Instead, particulars will be told they are taking part in two spot-the-difference tasks (the two change-detection tasks), as well as an eye-movement task (the middle saccade task), which are investigating visual perception. This is not deceitful, though it does withhold the true nature of the study from participants (namely, that the first task is assessing for any potential pre-existing bias towards green, and the second task is rewarding eye-movements specifically to green items).

In order to address this, participants will be initially asked to provide consent on the basis of two change detection tasks and an eye-movement task before testing takes place. Following the experiment, participants will be debriefed on the full nature of the task and will be asked to provide consent again. Any participant who does not wish their data to be kept in the study will be thanked for their time, provided course credits (if recruited via Sona), and their data shall be destroyed.

q13.value: Following a power analysis to ascertain required group sizes, 60 participants will be recruited. Participants will be staff and students at the University of Sunderland, as well as other volunteers recruited via social media advertisements (see later for advertisements). Participants will be over the age of 18, with no history of an addictive behaviour who have normal or corrected-to-normal vision with no colour blindness.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value: We want to investigate the reaction time and accuracy changes between change detection before and after attentional bias training.

The outcome variables are reaction time in milliseconds from the start of the trial until a response was made, and accuracy as percentage correct trials for each level of the trial type variable, for the change blindness task before and after the attentional training. 

Trial type had 4 levels, Congruent Change (green circle present and green circle change), Incongruent change (green circle present and different circle change), Neutral(green circle absent and circle change) and Control (green circle absent and no change). 

Additionally, for the attentional training task, both saccade reaction time in milliseconds (from the centre fixation until eyes moved over one of the shapes); and accuracy in present trials (measured as the percentage of eye movements toward a green hexagon) are both predictor variables. The criterion variable is the difference between reaction time for congruent trials before and after attentional training (the reaction time in the second change detection task for congruent trials only).

Reaction time for each participant will be calculated by taking the mean reaction time for correct trials only for each trial type, so four reaction time measures will be obtained

Accuracy will be calculated by summing the number of correct trials for each trial type dividing by the total number for each trial type and multiplying by 100, so four accuracy measures will be obtained.

Saccade reaction time will be calculated by using Pygaze's package for detecting saccades to obtain the duration of saccades through each trial. For each trial, saccade duration will be summed from the centre fixation at the start until eyes moved to one of the four shapes to obtain a total saccade duration. Then average saccade duration is calculated by taking the mean saccade reaction time for correct trial only.

Saccade accuracy is calculated as the sum of correct trials when target was present (green hexagon) divided by the total number of trials when target was present multiplied by 100

We will use two separate  2x3 repeated measures ANOVAs to analyse the difference in both reaction time and sensitivity to detect change (calculated via d'). The dependant variable is reaction time or perceptual sensitivity. The independent variables are Phase (which is repeated measures with two levels; before and after attentional training) and Trial Type (which is repeated measure with three levels; Congruent, Incongruent and Neutral). Bonferroni pairwise comparison will be conducted on the Trial Type variable.

Additionally, we will conduct a stepwise multiple regression to predict the difference in reaction time for congruent trials before and after attentional training (reaction time in the second change detection for congruent trial) from saccade reaction and attentional training accuracy.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 for determining if the ANOVAs, post hot test and regression suggest significant differences from the null hypothesis. Bonferroni pairwise comparison test will be used to adjust for multiple comparisons in the ANOVAs

q22.value: Participants will complete a practice block prior to all three phases of baseline, training and re-test in order to familiarise with the task. If participants score less than 80% accuracy overall they will be removed from the analyses. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any of the blocks, that subject will not be included in the analysis

registration_responses.q7: Participants will be unaware of the importance of the colour green throughout the study. This will not be referred to in the information sheets or any instructions given to participants. As such, participants will be unaware of the true purpose of the experiment regarding the creation of an attentional bias.
registration_responses.q9: As the experiment is a repeated measures task, no randomisation procedure is necessary.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Following a power analysis to ascertain required group sizes, 60 participants will be recruited. Participants will be staff and students at the University of Sunderland, as well as other volunteers recruited via social media advertisements (see later for advertisements). Participants will be over the age of 18, with no history of an addictive behaviour who have normal or corrected-to-normal vision with no colour blindness.
registration_responses.q14: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.
registration_responses.q21: We will use the standard p<.05 for determining if the ANOVAs, post hot test and regression suggest significant differences from the null hypothesis. Bonferroni pairwise comparison test will be used to adjust for multiple comparisons in the ANOVAs
registration_responses.q22: Participants will complete a practice block prior to all three phases of baseline, training and re-test in order to familiarise with the task. If participants score less than 80% accuracy overall they will be removed from the analyses. Outliers will be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q23: If a subject does not complete any of the blocks, that subject will not be included in the analysis
registration_responses.q8.question:
The study shall consist of three stages of testing - baseline, training and re-test. Stage 2 will use an eye-tracker. Stages 1 and 3 need only a computer screen and keyboard.

Stages 1 and 3 shall be identical and will be used to examine the baseline levels of attentional bias (stage 1) and potential modifications of attentional bias (stage 3) caused by the middle stage. This shall be achieved via a one-shot change-detection task which is an established method used to examine for attentional biases (Knight et al., 2016; 2018). The one-shot change-detection task will follow the following format: The experiment will begin with the presentation of a fixation cross for 1000ms followed by the stimulus array for 1500ms. The stimulus array will be a black screen with a circular array of six different coloured circles on it, all of the same size. The array will be masked for 100ms (by a completely blank screen), after which the stimulus array will re-appear. When it re-appears, one of the circles in the array may have changed colour into a different colour not currently present. Stimuli will remain present until a response is made. In 25% (45 trials) of trials a green item will be present and will change colour (Congruent Change Trials), in 25% of trials a green item will be present in the display but a different circle will change colour (Incongruent Change Trials), in 25% of trials no green item will be present and one of the other circles will change colour (Neutral Change Trials) and in 25% of trials a green item will be present but no change will occur (No Change Trials). The position of the coloured items will vary randomly across trials. The colours the circles in the array can be will be: green, red, blue, pink, purple, grey, mustard or orange. Participants will be advised that a change can occur to any of the presented stimuli in any position in the array. Participants will be asked to respond as quickly, but as accurately as possible via a computer keyboard if a change occurred or not. Response buttons will be coded to participant handedness (e.g. right-handed participants: M = change / Z = no change). Participants will complete 3 blocks of 60 trials with a 5 minute break between each block.

Stage 2 of the study will be an eye-movement task. Here, participants will be presented with four different coloured shapes on a computer screen. In many trials (but not all), one of these shapes will be a hexagon. If a hexagon is present , it will always be green (though participants will not be told this). Participants will be asked to make an eye-movement towards the hexagon, if it is present, as quickly but as accurately as possible. Once an accurate eye-movement has been made to the hexagon, a new trial will start. If no hexagon is present, they will be asked to press the space bar to start the next trial. The location of the hexagon will vary randomly across trials and the colours and shapes of the distractors on the screen will also vary randomly. Each trial shall be separated by a blank screen for 1000ms to minimise fatigue. Participants will complete 3 blocks of 30 trials.

The data from Stage 1 and 3 (reaction time and accuracy) shall be compared to examine if the middle training stage altered participants ability to detect changes to green items. This shall be done via two repeated measures ANOVAs - one examining differences in stage 1 compared to 2 for each type of trial for reaction time, and the other doing the same for accuracy. Reaction time and accuracy towards green shapes in stage 2 shall also be examined, to ascertain that participants are engaging in the training task appropriately - thus, results from this stage of the experiment will only be analysed as a control and not as part of the overall findings from the experiment.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be primarily recruited through the University of Sunderland's SONA system and will receive course credits for participation through this. Other participants will be recruited via adverts on social media asking if they would like to take part in a spot-the-difference and eye-movement task. Adverts will provide the email address of the two co-investigators (Helen Knight and Stephen Dunne) and will be asked to email either of the investigators to arrange a time for testing.

Full informed consent cannot be obtained from participants before taking part in this study, since previous research has shown that full informed consent when investigating attentional biases is one way to induce an attentional bias. Given that the current research is investigating the implicit development of an attentional bias, the word 'green' nor the mention of biases of attention can be presented to participants before testing has occurred. Instead, particulars will be told they are taking part in two spot-the-difference tasks (the two change-detection tasks), as well as an eye-movement task (the middle saccade task), which are investigating visual perception. This is not deceitful, though it does withhold the true nature of the study from participants (namely, that the first task is assessing for any potential pre-existing bias towards green, and the second task is rewarding eye-movements specifically to green items).

In order to address this, participants will be initially asked to provide consent on the basis of two change detection tasks and an eye-movement task before testing takes place. Following the experiment, participants will be debriefed on the full nature of the task and will be asked to provide consent again. Any participant who does not wish their data to be kept in the study will be thanked for their time, provided course credits (if recruited via Sona), and their data shall be destroyed.
registration_responses.q16.question: We want to investigate the reaction time and accuracy changes between change detection before and after attentional bias training.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The outcome variables are reaction time in milliseconds from the start of the trial until a response was made, and accuracy as percentage correct trials for each level of the trial type variable, for the change blindness task before and after the attentional training. 

Trial type had 4 levels, Congruent Change (green circle present and green circle change), Incongruent change (green circle present and different circle change), Neutral(green circle absent and circle change) and Control (green circle absent and no change). 

Additionally, for the attentional training task, both saccade reaction time in milliseconds (from the centre fixation until eyes moved over one of the shapes); and accuracy in present trials (measured as the percentage of eye movements toward a green hexagon) are both predictor variables. The criterion variable is the difference between reaction time for congruent trials before and after attentional training (the reaction time in the second change detection task for congruent trials only).
registration_responses.q18.question:
Reaction time for each participant will be calculated by taking the mean reaction time for correct trials only for each trial type, so four reaction time measures will be obtained

Accuracy will be calculated by summing the number of correct trials for each trial type dividing by the total number for each trial type and multiplying by 100, so four accuracy measures will be obtained.

Saccade reaction time will be calculated by using Pygaze's package for detecting saccades to obtain the duration of saccades through each trial. For each trial, saccade duration will be summed from the centre fixation at the start until eyes moved to one of the four shapes to obtain a total saccade duration. Then average saccade duration is calculated by taking the mean saccade reaction time for correct trial only.

Saccade accuracy is calculated as the sum of correct trials when target was present (green hexagon) divided by the total number of trials when target was present multiplied by 100
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use two separate  2x3 repeated measures ANOVAs to analyse the difference in both reaction time and sensitivity to detect change (calculated via d'). The dependant variable is reaction time or perceptual sensitivity. The independent variables are Phase (which is repeated measures with two levels; before and after attentional training) and Trial Type (which is repeated measure with three levels; Congruent, Incongruent and Neutral). Bonferroni pairwise comparison will be conducted on the Trial Type variable.

Additionally, we will conduct a stepwise multiple regression to predict the difference in reaction time for congruent trials before and after attentional training (reaction time in the second change detection for congruent trial) from saccade reaction and attentional training accuracy.

attributes.title: COVID-19: social cognition, mental health, and social distancing
attributes.description: Investigate the relationship between social cognition, mental health, and social distancing

copyright_holders: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai (neurocpu.org)

q2.value: At the core of our social relationships are our representations of the self and other people. Indeed, even during normal times, self- and other- perceptions have already been shown to influence our social perception, preference, and learning (Sui and Gu, 2017). Importantly, aberrant self and other representations are highly prevalent across a wide range of psychiatric disorders (Sui and Gu, 2017) such as major depressive disorder (MDD) (Northoff, 2007) and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) (Chiu et al., 2008). Depressed individuals, for example, typically have a heightened focus on the self which divert attention from the external world and result in rumination (Northoff, 2007). Based on this literature, we hypothesize that an excessive focus on the self, such as being caused by COVID-19, might contribute to worse mental health outcomes (depression, anxiety, loneliness, etc.). We also hypothesize that greater other-regarding preference, along with more accurate estimation of uncertainty and better access to COVID information,  contributes to better social distancing practice, which could be informative for public health policy.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This will be a longitudinal study with weekly follow-up of 1,500 subjects over the next 8-12 weeks (depending on COVID situation). Subjects will be recruited online (e.g. prolific.co). Subjects will be given gamified versions of well validated cognitive tasks that measure social cognition and choice behavior.  They will also complete surveys assessing their mental health and COVID related behaviors.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited online (e.g. through prolific.co). They will be paid a $7.25 hourly rate plus task bonus and completion bonus (i.e. after they complete the entire longitudinal study).  Participants must be at least 18 years old and currently live in the United States.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 1500 for the first time point.

q12.value: As this is a longitudinal study of 8-12 weeks, we decide to recruit 1500 in order to have a final target of n=1000 (e.g. considering a weekly drop out of 5-8%). While G'Power of our laboratory study suggests that n=30 will give us >0.8 power of detecting an effect at 0.05, one of the sub-aims is to compare the geographical distribution of the measures we will be using. Thus for each state we will need on average 20-30 subjects and a total of 1000-1500.

q13.value: Our previous experience with collecting online data suggests that we usually have at least 30-50 signups each hour. We expect to collect each time point within the same day (24 hours). We will stop after every 24 hours of data collection or completing all 1500 slots, whichever comes first.

question.value:
There are a total of 5 games / cognitive tasks. We manipulated the following for each task.
1) Self tagging: number of self/friend/other trials, number of matched vs non-matched trials.
2) Altruism task: payoffs to self vs other, number of trials.
3) Social control task: proposed offers by the partner; controllability of the social interactions.
4) Fish task: color of fish each trial, the pond from which the fish is drawn from.
5) Gamble task: probability (risk levels) and rewards.

Self tag task: accuracy and reaction time (RT)
Altruism task: % of selfish and altruistic choices
Social control: acceptance and rejection behaviors
Fish: choice of pond color
Gamble: risky vs. safe choices
Surveys: depression, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive behaviors, loneliness, personality traits, COVID attitudes and behaviors, substance use.

For each cognitive task, we have a well validated computational model to capture the deep psychological mechanisms underlying each process. 
Self tag: drift diffusion model
Altruism task, social control: social preference (e.g. Fehr-Schmidt) and learning (e.g. reinforcement learning) models.
Fish: Bayesian observer model
Gamble: risk aversion model
Global hypothesis: General linear modeling, Bayesian causal inference.
